list.name: Changes
list.comment:
1. In extract_text_from_image, added a new regex replacement for hours rows, where the hours values appear as one word (e.g., 12AM6AM). They should be spaced apart in order for the code to find them as words and identify the row as an HOURS AXIS.
2.Added a boolean for save_log_and_CSVs to RuntimeValues.py.
3. Made sure MISREAD_TIME_FORMAT_IOS cannot match a time like 73 minutes or 1 hour 493 minutes.
4. In extract_app_info, now allowing the truncated_initial_scan dataframe to include confident app names in the app area for Android screenshots only.
5. When consolidating overlapping text (in the app area), if one row matches a long time format but the previous row doesn't, then the previous row is dropped (and vice versa).

task.summary:
1. Added 'relative difference' to ETA csv
2. Added columns for 'same user' and 'different user' counts to Duplicate Screenshot Info csv
3. When showing images on screen, program now uses the current screen's height as a metric for how much to scale the image (so it fits on the screen).
4. Set maximum error_margin for two strings to be 7
5. Program now outputs a CSV of the confidence values of the data (as well as the data itself)
6. In AndroidFunctions.py: getting headings now uses two forms of a filtered row text (hashes instead of numbers, and that plus no spaces) in comparing row text to heading keywords. Helps to catch more headings.
Added 'updated_df' that prints to console whenever new data is compared to existing data (for a participant-day-category)
Added 'updated_df' that prints to console whenever new data is compared to existing data (for a participant-day-category)
Trying out a new ETA calculation, based only on the 50 most recent screenshots (of each OS version), instead of averaging ALL of them.

New method of detecting hours axis seems to be working just as well as the old method.
Also, found out why '00 06 12 18' was being replaced with '0 6 12 18' --- it has to do with the 'ensure_text_is_string' function in the extract_text_from_image function -- that function converted each word to an integer (if possible), then back to a string.

1. In extract_text_from_image, added a new regex replacement for hours rows, where the hours values appear as one word (e.g., 12AM6AM). They should be spaced apart in order for the code to find them as words and identify the row as an HOURS AXIS.
2.Added a boolean for save_log_and_CSVs to RuntimeValues.py.
3. Made sure MISREAD_TIME_FORMAT_IOS cannot match a time like 73 minutes or 1 hour 493 minutes.
4. In extract_app_info, now allowing the truncated_initial_scan dataframe to include confident app names in the app area for Android screenshots only.
5. When consolidating overlapping text (in the app area), if one row matches a long time format but the previous row doesn't, then the previous row is dropped (and vice versa).

MESSAGE.value:
1. Added 'relative difference' to ETA csv
2. Added columns for 'same user' and 'different user' counts to Duplicate Screenshot Info csv
3. When showing images on screen, program now uses the current screen's height as a metric for how much to scale the image (so it fits on the screen).
4. Set maximum error_margin for two strings to be 7
5. Program now outputs a CSV of the confidence values of the data (as well as the data itself)
6. In AndroidFunctions.py: getting headings now uses two forms of a filtered row text (hashes instead of numbers, and that plus no spaces) in comparing row text to heading keywords. Helps to catch more headings.
Added 'updated_df' that prints to console whenever new data is compared to existing data (for a participant-day-category)
Trying out a new ETA calculation, based only on the 50 most recent screenshots (of each OS version), instead of averaging ALL of them.

New method of detecting hours axis seems to be working just as well as the old method.
Also, found out why '00 06 12 18' was being replaced with '0 6 12 18' --- it has to do with the 'ensure_text_is_string' function in the extract_text_from_image function -- that function converted each word to an integer (if possible), then back to a string. The problem is now resolved, and the HOURS AXIS detection method no longer needs to include searches for '0' and '6', it can just include '00' and '06' (since that's how the hours row may appear on certain iOS screenshots).

New method of detecting hours axis seems to be working just as well as the old method.
Also, found out why '00 06 12 18' was being replaced with '0 6 12 18' --- it has to do with the 'ensure_text_is_string' function in the extract_text_from_image function -- that function converted each word to an integer (if possible), then back to a string. The problem is now resolved, and the HOURS AXIS detection method no longer needs to include searches for '0' and '6', it can just include '00' and '06' (since that's how the hours row may appear on certain iOS screenshots).

1. In extract_text_from_image, added a new regex replacement for hours rows, where the hours values appear as one word (e.g., 12AM6AM). They should be spaced apart in order for the code to find them as words and identify the row as an HOURS AXIS.
2.Added a boolean for save_log_and_CSVs to RuntimeValues.py.
3. Made sure MISREAD_TIME_FORMAT_IOS cannot match a time like 73 minutes or 1 hour 493 minutes.
4. In extract_app_info, now allowing the truncated_initial_scan dataframe to include confident app names in the app area for Android screenshots only.
5. When consolidating overlapping text (in the app area), if one row matches a long time format but the previous row doesn't, then the previous row is dropped (and vice versa).

2.Added a boolean for save_log_and_CSVs to RuntimeValues.py.
3. Made sure MISREAD_TIME_FORMAT_IOS cannot match a time like 73 minutes or 1 hour 493 minutes.
4. In extract_app_info, now allowing the truncated_initial_scan dataframe to include confident app names in the app area for Android screenshots only.
5. When consolidating overlapping text (in the app area), if one row matches a long time format but the previous row doesn't, then the previous row is dropped (and vice versa).
